We received the bonus as promised after the 6 month waiting period. The branch we use is conveniently located inside the Kroger store within walking distance of our home. I remember walking over to the store around 8pm one evening & the Chase people were still there working! Each time I stop and talk with any of the Chase representatives, they answer all of my inquiries & offer to help us anytime with our banking needs. Chase has what I consider to be the best online banking website, a person can snap a picture of a check & have it deposited without leaving home! We are very happy with Chase & their banking representatives, so glad we switched over!

name: Kristina
review: I have been with Chase bank for about four years now and I have not had many problems with them.  I have a checking and a savings account with them.  The bank tellers are always very friendly and willing to help you in any way that they can.  The only problem I have had with them was involving the over draft fees which are normally about $25.00.  They were not very lenient with reversing the fees even when I had a good reason behind it.  Other than that I would definitely recommend that you use this bank whether its with a checking or savings account.

name: Spencer Tracy
review: Chase is everywhere in the New Orleans and Baton Rouge area, allowing me to use their ATMs without incurring any fees. When I have questions about moving funds from checking to savings the employees are more than helpful and handle the questions and/or process with efficiency. I can not complain about my experience with Chase bank in terms of efficiency and accuracy in banking. They are convenient and also offer minimal fees which makes them the best bank for my needs in the local area. I deposit a high number of small checks per month and they always handle the process quickly and open up the funds immediately even if the checks come from a small out of state bank; this allows me to function without worrying about the little snags that I have had to handle with other banking institutions.

name: Mimi kiyoi
review: This might be truthfully the best credit card ever. You get so many rewards that it just makes life much easier. I have gained so many rewards so far. And you definitely have nothing to lose at all. I would no doubt totally recommend them.  But its not my choice. But also think of it this way. If you want great rewards for only doing what you always do then join. Them and with chase they know that gas prices are very expensive but luckily they have gas rebates that you can earn. It makes them more reliable and fun. I totally hope some of you guys take a break and decide to go check them out because they are safe and they have the best rewards.

name: Matthew Steen
review: With as much travel as I do, the combination of earning Marriott Points and the lower-than-average international transaction fee made this an ideal card for me.  The point redemption process is simple and easy, and I've received several free nights every year since I started carrying this card.  I've also found the customer service representatives to me amongst the most helpful out of any I've previously worked with.  The only negative is the fee, but so far I've earned enough free nights to more than make up for it.  I actually just used my points over Memorial Day weekend, and was reminded how pleased I am with this card!

name: Jus Shawna
review: I've had the Chase Freedom Visa card for about a year and love it! The cash back program is especially nice. Every few months, they offer double cash back at specific places like gas stations or Amazon (places I shop regularly). I use the card for purchases that fall into these cash back categories and can redeem the points for a check they send to me. The points are generous and customer service has always been very helpful. As long as the balance is paid every month and the card is used wisely, I think this is one of the better choices in credit cards available!

name: Jennifer Leighton
review: To put it simply, we love, love, love our Disney Visa card!  But, really, how can you not like a credit card that gives you so many perks?  Discounts at the Disney Store, discounts on Disney merchandise and, of course, you can earn points towards Disney vacations!  One of the nicest features of the card are the numerous special perks you can enjoy while on vacation in the Disney parks – VIP treatment, priority service and a host of other special details to make your Disney vacation even more magical!  We definitely take advantage of all the Disney Visa card has to offer!

name: Mike Water
review: I got this card because I already do my banking business with Chase, and I find that you have to handle it the same way that you handle them. Be very careful about your finances, and you'll be ok. But don't slip up! The intro rate is great, but you have to be careful when looking at your future payments. They have been slowly increasing my credit line, which works well for me because I can use my card for big expenses and then simply pay them off. However, if you're in a crunch and need money that you're not sure how you will pay back, be wary. The charges are a little on the steep side, and their customer service is a little bit lacking. As long as you stay on top of your finances and don't cross the boundaries, you should be happy with this card as well.

name: June Yarzabal
review: Very poor customer service with Hyatt. They do not honor their free nights. They expire in less than a year and hide that fact in micro sized print. Forget this one. Horrible experience with Hyatt when trying to redeem this. Rude and unresponsive personnel.

name: Cristen Fitzpatrick
review: I love my Slate from Chase credit card. The no balance transfer fees are an excellent thing, and it is something I considered before enrolling for this card. And I also take advantage of the Blueprint offer, in which I do not pay interest if I pay off certain purchases within the month. Chase makes it easy to see what my minimum monthly balance is and how much of it is Blueprint charges when I log on to their website to view my account. It is also extremely easy to pay my monthly balance online – even on the day that it is due!

name: Roger Brooks
review: I applied for this credit card after receiving a offer in the mail.  The offer stated that I would receive a bonus after making $500 dollars in purchases.  I really did receive the bonus.  That was appreciated.  Every three months I can sign up online to earn extra cash rewards.  I can also follow my spending online.  They have a place on the web site where I can see my cash back bonus that I’ve earned.  I like that this is a Visa credit card so it is accepted at many places.  Overall I think this is a good credit card and Chase seems to treat me well.

name: Susan Bain
review: I was responsible. I paid my bill religiously and on time. I had increased my credit from an initial $500 up to $5000, and then, over time, I paid off my Chase card completely. One month, I realized they had cut my credit line all the way back down to $500. I called customer service and was told that I am expected to use at least 85% of my credit line at all times. “Ma’am,” the agent told me, “Chase Bank doesn’t give you credit to use it only in emergencies.” One month I couldn’t make my rent and I called Chase to see if they would increase my limit again so I could make my rent payment. They increased it by $300 which was not enough. Chase Bank does not want you to use your credit wisely. They will not be there for you when you need them. They have no policy regarding customer loyalty.

name: Won Lee
review:
One thing that could have resulted in huge drop in your credit limit is if you have, elsewhere, done something or have something happen to you, that lowered your credit score dramatically. Normally, once you are approved for a credit card, a credit card companies won't check your score again, unless an urgent notice is sent to them. 

But, regardless, that Chase agent was douche to you, and deserves all the criticism he/she is rightfully due.

name: David Sanders
review: This is my third attempt to post this review as the WalletHub website keeps crashing on my computer! This is a great card for Amazon.com users/fans as it offers triple rewards for shopping on Amazon. We generally use it for the purchases and then pay the balance with the cash we would have spent thus earning ourselves a pretty handsome amount of rewards since we took out the card. The best part about the rewards is how easy they are to use, you can just shop on Amazon and when you are checking out they offer you the option of using your rewards points for their cash value on the purchase. I don't really care about the rates because I haven't carried a balance on the card, but I'm sure it is comparable to others. The only downside to the card is the issuer, Chase is not my favorite and they haven't proven to have pretty poor customer service, but I'll keep the card despite this drawback.

name: Lumière Bass
review: I got the Chase freedom card a while ago and so far so good! I recieved the zero percent APR for 12 months and got a great sign up bonus.  I wasn't sure about getting a credit card at first, but Chase has been a good choice so far.  I like the cash back (or credit back)  and five percent cash bonus categories.  My favorite category was definitely Amazon ( since I use it so much!).  Chase also has some great online tools to help you keep your debt at bay.  The main thing about credit cards in my opinion os using them wisely.  If you can do that, chase has a lot of great perks!

name: Rocco Hosta
review: Great Card. I'd already had a traditional Chase Visa and a Chase checking account. On a visit to the bank, the teller convinced me to open a Freedom card. I reluctantly agreed, but it is now my primary card. I the 0% intro APR for 6 months, and in that time I racked up about $75 worth of cashback while having no finance charges. My APR is now at somewhere around 15%, which is the norm for me, but I try to keep it paid down. If not, the rewards help nullify any of the interest charges I accrue. I do make sure to go out of my way to use this card for any of the quarterly 5% cashback categories; I've paid for every single grocery visit in the last two months exclusively with this card. The rewards definitely end up adding up. I've had no problems with this card, or with Chase as a bank. Would recommend this card to others looking for their first rewards card.

name: Jessica Gerig
review: This has been one of the best cards we have ever had! We are a Disney family through and through so this card has been quite helpful. Our family takes yearly trips to Disney World and when we use this card to pay for our resort hotel, tickets and even prizes and food in the parks we save a ton of money. You can get up to 30% off of your resort stay and many other perks that make this card well worth it. You can use your card in the parks as a VIP pass to exclusive character meet and greets that will leave huge smiles on your childrens faces! Also, every dollar you spend earns you reward points that you can use towards future trips or even online at the disneystore.com website. The perks are endless and the customer service is top notch. I have never been treated better by any other credit card company. Our family uses and values this card to make our yearly dreams come true. Thank you Disney and Chase for a great card!

name: Jessica
review: I have been a chase customer for about three years. Prior to that I was a customer of Washington Mutual whose branches became associated with Chase a few years ago. I have always had a positive experience at Chase. The tellers are patient and kind. The only problem I encountered with Chase was after I got married. Their paperwork policy for name changes is stricter than the federal government, which made changing my name a bit of a hassle and quite frustrating. The tellers were always very nice; it was the Chase policy that was the issue. Aside from that issue I have not had any problems with my finances through Chase. Their online banking accessibility makes depositing money and checking my balance very easy. Whatever time of night I know that I can deposit a check and it will show up in my account quickly by using the ATM. The option to view the check on your receipt after depositing it through the ATM provides an extra degree of certainty. I have never had an argument with any Chase representative, and I can rest assured that I am in control of my money at all times.

name: Jameson Smith
review: I love my Chase Sapphire Card.  Before I decided to sign up for it I never understood what all the fuss was about with points and rewards and other awesome perks you can earn.  Now its the only card I use on all of my purchases.  You would have to have a caravan of horses to pull this card away from me!  The commercials are what bought me to the Sapphire card and I'm sure glad they did, it really has changed my life for the better.  I would highly recommend this card to anyone that's unsure of it and I've referred a lot of my friends and family to this exclusive club.

name: Rachel Ham
review: My husband and I got this credit card initially because of the zero percent interest for twelve months, but little did I know after the twelve months it would jump up to like an eighteen percent interest rate! I mean it said so in the fine print, but who really pays attention to that! Now we are well over the two thousand dollar limit and can only pay the minimum balance each month & it is getting me no where! Every month I am basically just paying the interest! There are some good things about this credit card though! The more you spend you earn points & can buy gift cards with them! They have a good variety of major restaurant chains & we have earned quite a few fifty dollar gift cards! If you can pay it off before the interest is due then this credit card is for you! I honestly feel like the good outweighs the bad when it comes to the Chase Freedom Credit Card!

name: WalletHub
review: Those teaser rates can really hurt when they expire. You're definitely not alone as a credit user, a great many people find their debts much harder to manage once their introductory periods end.

name: Megan Wentworth
review: I use my Marriott visa whenever I make a big purchase and the miles really add up fast.  Also being silver status from the card is nice.  You get a few perks because of this.  I have never had trouble with customer service if I have had a question or concern with the account.  The APR is competitive too.  I would recommend this card to anyone.  You might as well get something back if you will be spending the money anyway and who wouldn't want to have some of your vacation paid for?  Incidentally, I have gotten a free night each year just for having the card in addition to the original free nights.  Basically the annual fee pays for itself if you like to travel.

name: Bryan Cubbins
review: Chase credit cards are awesome. This one is especially great because you get to rack up the rewards. I have had this card for about a year now and have had no trouble with it. On top of earning the great rewards, I also love the customer service. If you are looking for a great card I strongly recommend this one. I haven't found another card that I have used that has come anywhere close to offering me this kind of rewards. Go ahead and check out for yourself and see if you can find one that is better!

name: Lindsay Ang
review: I have been using this Chase card for almost two years. The things about Chase is they offer a lot of different rewards that you could get just from using their service. Chase is my primary bank and I have benefited a lot from their reward programs over the years. There are different types of programs being offered and I do suggest picking the one that would benefit you the most from using it. There's the southwest card if you travel a lot, and other rewards card like disney and so on. All in all, this might be the best one card there is out there.

name: Oscar Laguna
review: Chase credit cards and in particular this one are terrible. Chase is a bank that has bad practices and makes you regret opening accounts with them.The initial rates maybe acceptable, but Chase is going to increase the interest rate at any time, without a reason or justification and to very high levels, such as 27%.  Thanks to the new credit card law at least Chase cannot increase the rate to old balances, but a few years ago Chase used to do that.The rewards program is good at the beginning but once you earn the initial rewards, it is very hard to accrue points.Finally, for this card you have to pay an annual fee.  That fees is not worthy, get a card from a bank that does not charge an annual fee!

name: Jennifer Tyndall
review: Chase bank has been an excellent bank for my checking account. I have been with them for 12 years, since I was a young teenager and received my first job. The over all customer service of Chase bank has always been great. If I ever had any discrepancies with my account they always took care of them over the phone and in person. I have always received great service from the bank locations I have been to when doing transactions inside and also through the drive up service. I plan to continue staying with Chase bank as I overall have had nothing but great service from them with my checking account.

name: h
review: I have been with chase for a year now and my husband has been with the bank for 3 years, and in my opinion compare to other banks this is a much better bank. The staff is very helpful and the customer representatives on the phone are very helpful too. They taught us how to save and use the money in investments to get a better return. It has a great way of doing online business and is very reliable. The concept of instant transfers has made life so much easier for both of us. I would not hesitate before telling people to switch to chase.

name: Yurel Cooke
review: Chase was my primary bank when it was Washington Mutual. Since the change I found myself to be very upset at the major changes in customer service. Anytime that I contact customer service, it is a major hassle. I'm usually on hold for a long time. I'm lucky if the call takes less than twenty five minutes because the agents are quick to put you on hold to get an answer for the most simple of questions. I no longer use Chase as my primary bank just because of its customer service. I have since gone to Capital One for my primary banking services. If it was not for my fiance, I would have completely closed my accounts with Chase. I love how it is very easy to find a branch no matter where I am. I downloaded the app on my iPhone where I can deposit my checks via mobile device, but it hardly ever works and the app never recognizes my image of the check. Chase needs to do a complete overhaul of its customer service and conduct better training for their agents.

name: Nicole N
review: I have been a long time customer of Chase, and have had very good experiences with them.  Everything from the website functionality and being able to check my balance at any time, all the way to the customer service at the bank branch locations.  And there were two times over the course of several years in which I overdrew my account through no fault of my own, and both times Chase agreed to reverse some, if not all, of the charges.  I believe they only allow that once a year, but they were understanding and did not charge me the overdraft fees, which was a very nice way to handle a long term customer. Overall my experience with them has been very positive.

name: Mariela Echeverry
review: DO NOT sign up for this card.  I just called to cancel this card and was told that my Continental frequent flier account that I have had for 15 years will be cancelled because that freq. flier number was linked to my Continental (now United) credit card.  AND ALL MILES earned with the credit card will be forfeited.  Apparently I was sent a letter a few months ago communicating this.  DO NOT sign up for this card.

name: Won Lee
review: agree with war mab. not true.

name: Keenan Korbar
review: I signed up for this and now I am really regretting it. I got my bill in the mail and it showed interest charges at a rate of 22.9%, the worst they offer.  I have excellent credit and should've had no problem being granted the 0% APR but at least I should've been granted the 12.9%.  Either way on my first bill it showed no interest charge and now on the second bill it shows the 22.9% charge.  I called and e-mailed and they will not change the APR rate to 0% like it's supposed to be.  I'll be cancelling this card asap.

name: WalletHub
review:
hmm - this is very interesting - did you definitely apply for this Chase Freedom offer and if yes when did you apply? 

The Freedom Card listed on this page does NOT even have the option to get approved and NOT get the 0%. Everyone who gets approved should get 0% for 15 months. Please let us know and we will ask Chase to look into your situation because it is concerning... Thanks for bringing this to our attention.

name: Joe Weider
review: I like the Chase Liquid Prepaid Card’s branding a lot.  It’s got a sleek look and a catchy name that reminds people of water (which is calming) and cash (which we all obviously love), but you shouldn’t open any card for its branding.  You want it to save or make you the most money possible; that will make you far happier than having a pretty card that hurts your wallet.  Anyway, let’s see if Chase’s first prepaid card is more than just a pretty face.The first thing that strikes me about the Chase Liquid Card (besides its look of course) is the small number of fees that it charges.  Besides the $4.95 monthly fee, you won’t really get charged for much.  Chase ATM withdrawals are free, customer service is free, there’s no inactivity fee or anything.  From what I’ve seen prepaid cards are best used as fill-ins for checking accounts or to teach kids how to handle money.  I wouldn’t use the Liquid Card as a checking account because the Orchard Bank Prepaid Card is free if you load something like $1,000 a month.  The Liquid Card doesn’t allow you to escape the monthly fee, and it doesn’t have a bill pay option as far as I’ve seen.  Using it for teaching your child isn’t a bad idea though because kids aren’t going to deposit that much anyway.Bottom line, the Chase Liquid Prepaid Card is an interesting offer because it’s likely to be one of the first big bank prepaid cards introduced in the coming months, and it’s interesting to see whether the offers the big boys come up with can compete with the top dogs already in the prepaid card market.  Also it will be interesting to see whether Chase adds a way to escape the Liquid Card’s fees to let it compete more with the Orchard Card.

name: Margie Cole
review: Lookie here, a Chase prepaid card.  Looks like everyone (including WalletHub, if I remember correctly) who predicted more prepaid cards hitting the market after the Federal Reserve fussed with debit card fees were right.  Nice work! Anyway, I’m not going to even try to understand the minute details that went into this cause and effect.  But I always like taking a critical eye to a new card offer, and the Liquid Card from Chase definitely isn’t going to escape the Margie Treatment! Boom, pro/con time:Pros-	Number of Fees:  Looking at other prepaid cards, all you see is fee after fee after fee, and if you’ve ever tried to pick a prepaid card to open, you know this makes it so annoying to predict a card’s cost and judge whether it will be more or less expensive than another one.  I don’t mean to say that the Chase Liquid Card is perfect, it’s got fees, but it doesn’t have as many as say the Approved Card from Suze Orman.-	Overall cost:  The Chase Liquid Prepaid Card can be as cheap as $4.95/mo. which puts it in the upper echelon of prepaid cards, and potentially even less expensive than the GreenDot Visa for some people.-	Free live customer service might not seem like a pro since it should be standard but a lot of prepaid cards charge for it.-	Name:  I’m sure a lot of people will be more comfortable using a prepaid card from a name bank like Chase instead of one called BabyPhat, Mango, etc.Cons-	Overall cost:  This is both a pro and a con since the GreenDot Card can be free for some of ya’ll.-	The GreenDot Card gives you a chance to avoid a monthly fee by loading a certain amout, but the Liquid Card doesn’t, which seems like a shame to me.  There’s a cap to how good this offer can be.-	Potential for high ATM fees:  If you don’t live near a Chase ATM, you’ll have to choose between what’s most convenience and what’s cheapest, and when things get buys most of us choose convenience.When you got down to it, the prepaid card market just got a bit better today with Chase’s introduction of its new prepaid card, the Liquid Card.  Its one of the better offers available, in my opinion, and I recommend it if you don’t live near a GreenDot ATM or don’t want to keep that much money in your new-era checking account, i.e. your prepaid card account.

name: Anthony Bey
review: American Express prepaid card is better. I've had mine for two years. Check it out

name: Brandon Bingham
review: not really ifyou have chase branches and ATMs near you.Its very easy to find a Chase near me and you can use their branch and atms for deposits and withdrawls

name: Margie Cole
review: WOW! Did everyone catch this card’s annual fee?  $395!  What does it print money or something? Is it magic?  There has to be something unique about the United MileagePlus Club Credit Card for Chase and United to feel it deserving of such a high price tag, so I made a little pro and con list to see if I could get to the bottom of things.Pros-	Initial bonus:  Getting a $95 statement credit after your first purchase is nice; only $300 to go before we break even with the United MileagePlus Club Card!-	Checked Bags:  Getting to check your first and second bags for free is nice, but doesn’t Southwest already offer that standard?-	Hotel Benefits:  Getting complimentary room upgrades, free breakfast and stuff is awesome, but I’d love for Chase to be a bit more specific about exactly what you get.Cons-	Club Access:  Club access is great, don’t get me wrong.  My problem with it though is that if you travel frewuently enough to need it, you’ll probably get it for free anyway.  Also I’ve seen a bunch of cards with reasonable annual fees offer it.-	Priority Borading:  I don’t see why people want to sit on a plane for longer.-	Ongoing rewards:  The United Plus Club Card gives you 1.5 miles across all purchases and 2 miles on United purchases, hardly deserving of a $400 annual fee.It was going to take a lot for me to think the United MileagePLus Club Card’s annual fee was worth it, and the card’s terms really didn’t show me that much.  I know I’m not going to get it as a result and don’t recommend you doing so either.

name: Margie Cole
review: The Hyatt Credit Card is decent, but I don’t see it as being a great option for anyone who isn’t a diehard Hyatt customer.  The reason is simple, it doesn’t offer enough value for someone who isn’t routinely staying at a Hyatt hotel and earning the 3 points per dollar that the Hyatt Card provides on Hyatt purchases.   This is especially true in light of the Hyatt Credit Card’s competition, which will become clear after this quick pro/con list.Pros-	2 Free nights:  You get 2 free Hyatt nights after your first purchase, and free hotel accommodations are always nice, especially with summer coming up.-	With a Hyatt Credit Card account, you get one free night each year on your cardholder anniversary.Cons-	2 Free Nights:  The Hyatt Card’s initial bonus is both a pro and a con given that it’s attractive in a vacuum but unattractive when considered along with the competition.  The Hilton Credit Card gives you up to 8 free nights and the Chase Sapphire Preferred offers $500 for travel or $400 in cash.-	Annual fee:  The Hyatt Credit Card charges a $75 annual fee, which pretty much counteracts the  free anniversary night.-	Ongoing rewards:  One point per dollar for non-Hyatt purchases isn’t great, and neither is the 3 points for Hyatt purchases, unless you’re constantly racking them up.-	No low interest rates:  Despite its lacking rewards, the Hyatt Credit Card is a rewards credit card through and through, seeing as it doesn’t offer 0% intro rates on purchases or transfers.Long story short, I wouldn’t get the Hyatt Card.  Instead, if an initial bonus is what I’m after, I’d go with the Chase Sapphire Preferred or the Hilton Card.  If I wanted ongoing travel rewards and I’m not a loyal Hyatt customer, I’d probably go with the Capital One Venture because it gives you basically 2% cash back when you redeem for travel of any kind.

name: Joe Weider
review: The last time I took a look at the Chase Ink Cash Business Credit Card, it only offered 0% on purchases and balance transfers for 6 months, which wasn’t very competitive.  Chase has obviously upped the ante with its revamped Ink Cash offer since it now offers 0% for 12 months.  Since business credit cards don’t have the same protection against random interest rate increases as personal credit cards, having a year of an assured 0% rate would be helpful for a small business owner looking to use a single credit card for business spending and funding.  It also lets people who want to do a balance transfer make purchases with their card without wasting a bunch of dough on interest that comes from not having a grace period (when you revolve a balance you don’t have one!).If I were in the market for small business cards, I still think I’d go with the Ink Bold with Ultimate Rewards and either the No Balance Transfer Fee Slate Card or one of the Citicards offering 0% for 18 months, depending on if I wanted to transfer a balance or just avoid interest on new purchases, instead of the Ink Cash.  The Ink Bold just offers better rewards and the others are personal cards with way longer 0% rates than the Ink Cash.  Whichever way you turn though, it’s clear that Chase is sure stepping up its game and is a major player in the low interest and business card areas.  I bet my man Won Buddy Lee is loving it, isn’t that right?

name: Margie Cole
review: Even though this offer seems like its changed a lot over the years, Id still get it if I didn’t care how my credit score was over the next few months.  I mean, I’m all for a free roundtrip Southwest Airlines flight.  With that being said though, the Southwest Airlines Credit Card may not be the best offer of its kind on the market right now and if you just want to open one credit card right now, it might not be for you as a result.  Why don’t we find out with a little pro and con.Pros-	Free flight:  I don’t want to give anything away, but I kind of think this is the Southwest Airlines Rapid Rewards Plus Credit Card’s only strength.Cons-	Ongoing rewards:  2 miles per dollar with Southwest and 1 per dollar everythere else isn’t too good especially since travel cards give you 2 miles on every purchase.-	Balance Transfer Offer:  The Southwest Airlines Rapid Rewards Card doesn’t have a 0% intro rate but has a balance transfer fee, so the one point per dollar it gives you on transfers isn’t worth it.  Youd be better off using the No Fee Slate Card.-	Purchase APR:  No 0% rate here either.Its clear thatn the only only reason youd use the SouthWest Rapid Rewards Credit Card is for its initial bonus, and if you want to do that go for it.  I wouldn’t do it in lieu of getting a card like the Chase Sapphire Preferred cause that offers $500 in travel,

name: Ashanti Knock
review: NOT WORTH signing up for this card... it's a scam to lure you in...  Was in the process of booking my flight when the deal for a $50 rebate came up to reduce the total costs...  Got approved 30 minutes later but did not qualify at the time of reserving the flight for the $50 rebate and other perks.  Spent over an hour on the phone with United and then another 20 minutes with Chase and I just cancelled the card altogether.  Will make me think twice using United again for the hassle I went through just for their United Mileage Plus Explorer Card.

name: Won Lee
review: Continuing the trend of arguing against both Joe and Margie,   I am telling you to go sign up for this card (once the bonus jumps back to $200 cash back), because there are tricks to really enhance this card that both Joe and Margie doesn't tell you. It's called,   Chase Tri-Fecta trick.   First you need 3 things: 1) Chase Freedom.2) Chase Sapphire preferred (or chase Ink Bold for Business).3) Chase Checking account. I will explain how first one work in this scheme, but let's start with other two.  Byhaving Chase sapphire Preferred  or Ink Bold,  u can transfer ultimate reward points (chase's bonus point system) into miles and hotel points. Since miles are most lucrative, let's stick with that.  and why is that important here? Because points you earn from Chase Freedom is really, ultimate reward points as well. With Freedom alone,  you can't transfer it to miles, but u can transfer ultimate reward points u earn from Freedom (200 cash back really means u get 20,000 ultimate reward points) to your Saph. Pref. or Ink Bold, and convert it to miles. So in essense, u are really getting $400 worth of free stuff, for a card that COSTS YOU ZERO EVERY YEAR. now, chase checking account. If you can open a chase checking account AND have chase freedom,  every single purchase, u get 10 reward points.  So those trips to vending machines? I put it on my chase freedom. then I get 11 (10 bonus +1 from purchase) for every king sized kit-kat bar I enjoy. on top of other things Joe and Margie mention, this is what makes this trifecta awesome.  you are literally getting cash back 6-11% (if u don't fly), or up to 22 % return by using the method above. get it?  so go get this card, and keep it forever (as long as T&C don't change).

name: Won Lee
review:
Joe Weider although i will never claim i understand general public when it comes to miles earning scheme (in my mind, why would they not?) you are absolutely right that this takes effort, which people might not give a darn about. In that sense, given how every quarter, you have to sign up all over again to get the 5% bonus, straight up earning is gonna be preferential to others. 

In that sense, i concur with you Joe Weider and @Margie Cole that cap1 venture might work better.  I concede that point.  (but which still brings me back to the point, why would they not do it???)

name: Won Lee
review: Joe is absolutely correct this card is geared toward getting you to spend time in Marriott.  But who are we kidding?  Unless you live somewhere out of nowhere. you probably stayed at marriott property at least once in your life. In fact, you probably spend at LEAST ONE night in Marriott per yr or so.   If you are someone who does, this card is great.    forget all the extra points(great), what makes this card great is you get a free hotel voucher each year (basically cancels out annual fee) + free silver status each year (because they give you 15 nights toward your membership level). other than that,  I suggest you still stay away from cap1 but head toward other chase cards, like chase sapph    or if your credit rating isn't high enough, go to chase freedom. i have this card, because I stay at marriott a lot,  and I use it exclusively at marriott (2 marriott point or 1 marriott point isn't worth the same as 1 airline miles to me).  no forex charge on this card means u can use it internationally, which is great.

name: Joe Weider
review:
You’re right @WonBuddyLee, most people have indeed stayed at a Marriott Hotel before and could make use of a free night or two, but unless someone stays in Marriott Hotels frequently, the odds are that they can make better use of their rewards by applying them to bigger priorities.  Most people don’t have more than a couple of credit cards and don’t want to deal with having more, so why waste the opportunity to get a card that will help you save hundreds on things like gas and groceries in order to get a free night on a trip you MIGHT take?

That’s why I recommended that only loyal Marriot customers get the Marriott Premier Credit Card and everyone else get a rewards card that complements their biggest spending categories, such as the Cap One Venture or the Amex Preferred.

name: Margie Cole
review: It’s baaack.  It sure seems like big initial bonus season or something  because Alec Baldwin has been firing up potential Capital One customers recently with the Venture Card’s Double Miles Challenge and Chase and British Airways just brought back the British Airways Credit Card’s 100,000 bonus mile deal.  In other words, you get 50,000 bonus miles for getting the British Airways rewards Card and making a single purchase, 25,000 additional bonus miles for spending $10,000 within the first year, and another 25,000 for spending another $10,000.  Sorry to get your hopes up because 100,000 bonus miles sounds a lot better than 50,000 plus the possibility of 25,000 more and the unlikely chance to get another 25,000.  Anyway, I think going over some of the pros and cons of the British Airways Credit Card.Pros -	You’re assured of at least 50,000 Avios points with the British Airways Credit Card and since you only need 12,500 to get a free economy cross country flight and 20,000 for a transatlantic one, that’s a pretty good deal in and of itself.-	If you spend enough to get the additional 50,000 bonus miles from the BA Credit Card, you’ll probably also be able get a free companion ticket each year…not too shabby.-	The British Airways Credit Card is obviously geared toward international travel, so while having no foreign transaction fees is expected, it’s nice to see nonetheless.Cons-	The ongoing rewards (2.5 Avios miles per $1 spent on BA and 1.25 on everything else) aren’t really anything of note, although if you do fly BA a lot, they will come in handy.-	The fact that the Chase British Airways Card is a “smartcard” doesn’t really mean much.  The caqrd doesn’t have a PIN, which means you wont be able to use it at train kiosks and stuff like that out of the country.-	My friend once got the BA Card and said that redeeming rewards miles is made very difficult by things like blackout dates and restrictions.-	A $95 annual fee isn’t what you like to see, but this card’s rewards have the potential to be worth it.All in all whether or not you get the British Airways Credit Card really depends on how much you travel and how often you do so with British Airways.  If you do both a lot, the BA Card should be in your wallet and you can be very happy about all the bonus miles.  If you want to use this card for a single European adventure or something like that, it could work, but you need to be flexible about when you travel.  I would not get this card if you never travel internationally and just want to maybe do so down the road because cash would be worth a lot more to u and the miles you get might go unredeemed.

name: Margie Cole
review: People looooveee getting free stuff from their credit cards, so much so that its easy to forget that this free stuff inevitably has a dollar value, which it’s important to find out and compare to the cash offers available from other cards.  I mean you could be wowed by the 6 free nights you can get by opening the Marriott Credit Card, but I personally have no idea what a category 1 hotel is and whether its on the good or bad end of the spectrum.  This is important because you should really only get a hotel or airline affiliated card, such as the Marriott Card, for ongoing use if you use that company’s services frequently and consistently.  The pool of people who could benefit from a good initial bonus would be much larger, however.  So read my likes and dislikes about the Marriott Rewards Credit Card with a sense of what group you’d fit into.Pros-	Depending on where you stay and when, the Marriot Card’s initial bonus should be worth somewhere in the $400 – 900 range, which is pretty great.-	The Marriott Credit Card gives you Marriott status points; you start off with Silver status and get 10 points toward Elite status; your status dictates the number of free goodies and services you get each time you stay.Cons-	Three points per $1 spent at Marriott Hotels isn’t that great as far as ongoing rewards are concerned.-	While there’s no annual fee in the first year, having to pay $45 a year thereafter for average ongoing rewards isn’t that great.So, for those of you considering applying for the Marriott Rewards Credit Card, here’s what I’d do.  If you stay at Marriott properties all the time, I’d pass on the Marriott Rewards Card for its Premier counterpart, the Marriott Rewards Premier Credit Card.  It has a better initial bonus and better ongoing rewards, so for the frequent Marriott customer, it’d be worth the $85 annual fee (beginning in the second year).  And since non-frequent customers would presumably only be getting the Marriott Credit Card for the initial bonus, I’d recommend that they get the Premier option too.  The thinking here is that you can get 7 or 8 free nights as opposed to 6 and probably wouldn’t keep your account open for longer than a year anyway.  Even if you want to, the free night you get each year would pretty much pay for the annual fee.  Ultimately the Marriott Premier Card is just a better Marriott Rewards Card than the Marriott Rewards Card itself.

name: John Valerio
review: I have this card. I like it. Customer Service is great. You never wait. Once you log in to your account, there are extra features to track spending in categories, produce some reports and set up payment schedule reminders and other services. great ready-made paperwork to email to your accountant. The Ultimate Rewards is a great bonus that Chase should advertise more. The Ink qualifies for it and you can earn points and discounts through a great variety of well-known merchants like Target, HP, Walmart, Kohls,  JCP, Sears, Best Buy and tons more. The 5% Cash back categories are pretty good though not overly lucrative for big ticket items. The 2% on gas is very useful. Good card to have for those 5% expenses and Ultimate Rewards. Other cards give better rewards for other categories if you don't mind carrying multiple cards.

name: Margie Cole
review: I’ve seen a few TV ads for the United Mileage Plus Explorer Card, so I thought I’d take a look at what its got.  After all, some of the ads you see on TV are for really great cards while others only make really average cards sound really good.  The United MileagePlus Explorer Credit Card requires excellent credit for approval, doesn’t have an annual fee in the first year (but charges $95/yr. after that), and offers an interesting initial bonus as well as some decent ongoing rewards and some assorted other perks.  I find it easiest to decide on whether a card is good or not by making a pro/con list, so here’s mine for the United Plus Explorer Card:Pros-	 25,000 bonus miles after first purchase (enough for a one-way ticket to Hawaii and nearly enough for one to Europe).-	United’s deep roster of rewards partners allows you to immediately transfer miles at full value to other travel companies’ rewards programs (e.g. British Airways, Amtrak, Hyatt Hotels).-	Assorted perks like Club passes, priority boarding, and free checked baggage not only make travel more comfortable, but less expensive as well.Cons-	You can’t get the extra 15,000 bonus points advertised if you don’t add an authorized user or spend a crazy amount each year.-	The miles per dollar spent are not competitive with the best travel rewards cards on the market.United has one of the most interesting travel rewards programs around, thanks to its many rewards partners and the deals it has struck with issuers like Chase that allow you to transfer, say, Chase rewards into United Miles and redeem them with any United travel partner.  In light of this latter consideration, you can benefit from United’s wide-ranging rewards program even if you don’t get a United credit card like the MileagePlus Explorer Card.  For example, you could get the Chase Sapphire Preferred card, which has an initial bonus worth $625 in travel, transfer this bonus to a United partner’s rewards program and benefit just the same.  You could likewise get any Southwest Airlines credit card, for example, and do the same.  With that being said, I’d compare all of the credit cards affiliated with United rewards and pick the most lucrative offer.  You could also get a card like the Capital one Venture Card, which offers miles that equate to 2% cash back on all purchases if you redeem them toward any travel-related expenses.  Also, if you don’t travel a lot, I’d go with a good cash back card like the Blue Cash preferred from Amex bc it will provide more consistent benefits.  Overall, what I hope is clear is the fact that United’s overall rewards program is even more exciting that what exactly the United MileagePlus Explorer Card offers, and those of you who can figure out how to strategically game the system will benefit big!

name: Margie Cole
review: Ok, there’s a lot going on here with the Chase Freedom Visa -- $100 initial bonus + 0% Intro APR offer.  Those last two things sound pretty good, and we’re all for freedom, so you might as well just apply for this Chase Freedom Visa, right?  Of course not, you need to compare what it offers to the best cards on the market because with the excellent credit that it takes to get the Chase Freedom Card, you’ll be able to get basically any credit card that you’d like.  To do that lets make a good old fashioned pro/con list.Pro-The Chase Freedom Visa obviously gives you a $100 initial bonus as well as a 0% intro APR (6 months on purchases and 12 months on transfers).- 5% cash back on rotating spending categories.-1% cash back on everything else.Cons-The $100 initial bonus is far less than what you could get from the Chase Sapphire Preferred ($500-625).- The 0% offer is not as good as three different CitiCards that offer 0% on both purchases and transfers for 18 moths or the No Balance Transfer Fee Slate, which offers 0% on both for 15 months and does not charge a transfer fee.-To get the 5% on rotating expenses, you have to sign up each quarter.Overall, the Chase Freedom Credit Card with the $100 initial bonus and 0% intro APR is pretty good, but not good enough.  This seems fairly representative of the credit card market these days; a lot of good offers, only a few great ones.  You already know whoch cards I’d recommend for low rates and initial bonuses, but if you want better rewards than what the Chase Freedom Visa Card offers, I’d go with the Blue Cash Preferred from Amex or the Capital One Venture Card.

name: Margie Cole
review: I know that $200 sounds really good.  I mean who wouldn’t want an extra $200 in their wallets?  The real question you want to ask though is how much is that $200 costing me?  If there’s another card out there that gives more than $200 and requires the same excellent credit you’d need to get the Chase Freedom Visa -- $200 Bonus Cash Back, you’d be giving up money in the process of applying for the Chase Freedom Card.  At any rate, I think it’s helpful to wrap your head around a credit card offer by simply making a pro and con list, so here’s mine:Pros•	$200 Free Cash.•	The chance to get 5% on certain types of purchases.•	1% cash back across all other purchases.Cons•	Must sign up on a quarterly basis for the 5% rewards.•	No 0% interest rates.•	The fact that the Chase Sapphire Preferred Card offers $500-625 in free dough.The truth is you’re not going to get the Chase Freedom Visa -- $200 cash back offer because of its ongoing rewards.  Its just too undependable and requiring of attention.  Youre going to get the Chase Freedom Visa because of its initial bonus and now that you know the Chase Sapphire Preferred offers a better one, you can cross the Chase Freedom off your list.

name: Margie Cole
review: I don’t often comment on sites like this, but I’ve been meaning to start because I feel that I have something valuable to contribute to all my fellow personal finance geeks out there and basically anyone looking to get a credit card. Wow, that may have come off as conceited, but trust me, anyone can figure out credit cards if they follow industry news; it’s just a hobby of mine, which some would probably call strange. Anyway, I don’t comment a lot, but I can’t resist telling people about a great deal, and that’s exactly what the No Balance Transfer Slate Card from Chase is. This card offers a 0% introductory APR on purchases as well as balance transfers for 15 months and true to its name, does not charge a balance transfer fee. If you were going to transfer $20,000 in credit card to the No Balance Transfer Slate Card, for instance, its lack of a balance transfer fee would save you $600 relative to a card charging the standard 3% fee. That’s not even the most interesting thing about the Slate Card with No Balance Transfer Fee. After this offer initially caught my eye, I read up on it a bit. Apparently, no transfer fee 0% cards were common a couple years ago but that 2010 personal finance law made the shady practices serving as their revenue source illegal. Nothing’s changed though, so I don’t really know how Chase can offer this card (and a lot of people smarter than me feel the same way). But it doesn’t really matter when you get down to it, now does it? I know I’m going to tell everyone I know to take advantage of Chase’s No Balance Transfer Fee Slate Card before it disappears, and you should too!

name: Margie Cole
review: I’m really feeling McDonald’s about all these initial bonuses were seeing credit card companies offer these days (get it, I’m lovin’ it!). Every time I look around there are new deals where you get thousands of points/miles or hundreds of dollars cash back for opening a new card and making a single purchase or spending a certain amount in the first few months. (Apparently, a bank cannot just give you the points/miles/cash back because it would then be taxable; thanks Citi!). At any rate, one of the best initial bonuses out there right now comes from the Chase Sapphire Preferred Card. When you open this card and spend at least $3,000 in the first three months, you get 50,000 bonus miles, which are worth either a $500 check/statement credit or $625 in hotels and airfare. $625, wow! Who knew such a little piece of plastic could pack such a big punch? The Chase Sapphire Preferred Card isn’t only about the initial bonus, but you should really pretend that is the case. The reason why is the Sapphire Preferred Card does not offer attractive ongoing rates or rewards. You only get 1-2 points per dollar you charge, depending on the type of purchase, as well as a 7% annual rewards dividend. This is not competitive compared to rewards credit cards like the Capital One Venture or the Blue Cash Everyday from Amex. The Chase Sapphire Preferred Credit Card doesn’t offer low introductory rates as would be the case with the Chase No Balance Transfer Fee Slate Card or a few different Citi credit cards either. So, my advice: Take the money and run to a different card for ongoing use.

name: Won Lee
review: I am gonna repeat what i said to Joe, to Margie. If you get this card to get it as 625$ hotel and airfare,  you should stay out of credit card business and just use cash or check card.   always transfer to airline miles, where the value is greater. 50k airline miles are worth at minimum $900 dollars,  and you should never cash out chase reward points.

name: Joe Weider
review: If youre in the market for a credit card with which to save on gas, you’ll likely start with those with specific stations in their names.  In doing so keep in mind that such cards only allow you to save on gas purchased at those specific stations, so if you’re not a brand loyal gas pumper, you won’t get as much value as you’d like from such a card.  Nevertheless, let’s see what the Hess Credit Card has to offer, as it’s likely to be a main consideration for a lot of consumers.  The Hess Rewards Credit Card gives you different gas savings depending on the time since you opened your account.  You see, during the first 60 days your account is open, the Hess Card will give you 10% off each net $1 you spend at Hess locations (up to $400 spent).  In other words, you can take up to $40 off your two-month Hess tab by using the Hess Credit card.  After that, you get 3% off Hess purchases.  The Hess Rewards Card also gives you 1% off purchases made everywhere else (except other gas stations, of course).  Overall, while this offer might sound good, you’d basically be sacrificing a better long-term rebate for up to $40 in the short term.  Since using the Hess Credit Card also pretty much requires that you only get gas at Hess stations, you also sacrifice logistical flexibility.If you’re a loyal Hess customer, opting for a credit card tied to a different gas station rather than the Hess Credit Card won’t help you because you’d also have to shift your consumption habits, not possible for most people.  Going with a generic gas rewards card instead of the Hess Rewards Card would be helpful though as such cards offer gas rewards no matter what station you fill up at.  The Pentagon Federal Credit Union Cash Rewards Card for example gives you 5% cash back on gas purchases paid at the pump as well as 1% on everything else.  While the Blue Cash Everyday card from Amex only gives you 2% on gas, it also gives you 3% at supermarkets, 2% at department stores, and 1% on everything else.  This combination of rewards will match up well with many people’s spending habits, at least a heck of a lot better than the Hess Credit Card’s will.

name: Joe Weider
review: Disney is said to be where dreams come true, but does this hold true with the Disney Premier Credit Card?  Let’s find out.  First of all, the Disney Premier Card requires good or excellent credit for approval and charges a $49 annual fee. That simply clues you into the fact that it better have some good rewards or long 0% intro terms because those things are available from cards with the same credit requirements and comparable, if not cheaper, annual fees.  Starting with rewards, the Disney Premier Credit Card offers a $100 statement credit after first use, 2% in Disney Dollars back on purchases made at gas stations, grocery stores, restaurants and Disney stores and locations; 1% back everywhere else.  It also offers 0% on purchases for six months.  The Disney Premier Card is therefore decent overall.  You don’t find many co-branded credit cards offering rewards on big expense categories like gas, groceries and dining, but the fact that each Disney dollar is worth an actual dollar only when redeeming for Disney goods and travel, the usefulness of these rewards is kind of limited.Some alternatives to the Premier Disney Credit Card are in order then.  The Chase Sapphire Preferred Card is a good option in the sense that it offers an initial bonus worth $625 in travel or $100 in cash.  The Blue Cash Everyday from Amex is also good because it offers 3% cash back at supermarkets, 2% cash back at gas stations and department stores and 1% cash back on everything else.

name: Joe Weider
review: Who wants to bet that Andy Bernard has the Cornell Credit Card?  If you, like him, are an ardent supporter of Cornell University or Big Red athletics, then you might consider getting the Cornell Card as well.  It’s never a good idea to open a financial product based on branding alone though (much less a sitcom character’s affinity), so we need to see what it offers before you hit that apply button.  With the Cornell Credit Card, you get 1 point for every $1 you spend, which you can redeem for a number of things, including cash gift certificates, travel, etc.  That’s it.  Oh, and you can only compile a maximum of 60,000 points each year.  There aren’t any 0% introductory rates either.  If you’ve read any of my other little credit card reviews, you know that this just isn’t going to cut it.  The best rewards programs a) don’t have rewards earning caps b) give you 1% cash back or 1 point per $1 spent as a base c) have much higher earning rates for certain spending categories.  The Cornell University Credit Card is therefore certainly not worth your hard earned good or excellent credit (though Cornell may have helped give you the smarts needed to get it), especially considering how much this credit standing can be worth via other cards.For example, the Chase Sapphire Preferred Card offers a $500-625 initial bonus; the Capital One Venture Card gives you 2% cash back across all purchases as long as you redeem miles for  travel related purchases; the Blue Cash Everyday Card from American Express gives you 3% cash back at supermarkets, 2% cash back at gas stations and department stores and 1% on everything else.  Each of these cards boasts better rewards than the Cornell University Card.  Oh, and lastly, the cool thing about Capital One credit cards is that you can personalize the entire front of em with pictures of your choice.  So you could take your favorite CU sports memory, picture of campus, or logo and make any card your very own Cornell Credit Card.

name: Joe Weider
review: There’s a lot about this Slate Card from Chase that stands out, but most notable is its shape and lack of a balance transfer fee.  These features are designed to catch your eye, and they certainly do accomplish that task, but what you have to figure out is whether the Slate Card – No Balance Transfer Fee is truly outstanding or just standing out.  The first thing ya gotta understand is that a balance transfer fee is just one of the costs to watch out for when transferring a balance (moving your debt from one credit card to another to get a lower interest rate).  The other primary cost obviously stems from the balance transfer interest rate you get and (since most cards these days are offering 0% introductory rates) how long it’s offered for.  You need to weigh all of these factors in evaluating any balance transfer card, including the Chase Slate no balance transfer fee offer.  The best way to compare balance transfer cards is to figure out how much you can afford to put toward your credit card debt each month and use a balance transfer calculator to figure out how long it will take you to pay it off.  That will make it easy to figure out how much of a balance would remain following the end of any card’s 0% intro rate.  Comparing the effects of interest incurred at this time to the money you’d theoretically save by having no balance transfer fee will tell you whether eschewing a longer 0% period for a card with no transfer fee would be a good idea.  The point is that you should not allow a credit card company’s marketing to influence your choice too much.  Credit card companies love to zero out a card’s terms in one area and typically offset this in other areas.  In other words, the Slate no balance transfer fee credit card might not actually be a better offer than certain cards that do have a balance transfer fee.I can’t tell you for certain which the best card is as so much depends on your individual situation, but some cards to check out are the Discover More Card and the three Citicards offering 0% for 18 months.  It’s also important to note that if a card advertises its 0% rate as a range (0% for 6-12 months), you shouldn’t assume or hope that you’ll get the high end.  How long you’ll get it for depends on your credit score.  The higher it is, the longer you’ll get it for.

name: Juliet Wyd
review: Is the Slate Card from Chase just a gimmick or does it really provide something unique?  That’s the first thing that pops into my head when I look at this card, which looks more like a hotel key than a credit card.  To answer this initial query, though, I had to take a closer look at the details of what it offers.  First of all, the Slate from Chase requires good or excellent credit for approval and does not have an annual fee.  That initially tells you that the Slate Card probably doesn’t have the best possible rates or rewards (those usually come with a fee) but that it better have some attractive terms to warrant someone with exemplary credit standing submitting an application.  Well, Chase’s Slate Card does not have rewards, so it all comes dwon to its rates.  It offers 0% on purchases and transfers for 15 months.  Unfortunately, this does not stack up with the competition.The Citi Simplicity, Diamond Preferred, and Platinum Select Cards all offer 0% on purchases and transfers for 21 months and, like the Slate Credit Card from Chase, do not have annual fees.  The Discover More Card, like the Slate Card, also offers 0% for 15 months, but it gives you rewards too.  Speaking of rewards, if you were checking out the Slate Card simply because you saw it on TV and are interested in getting rewards, a couple of cards to check out are the Venture Card from Capital One and the Chase Sapphire Preferred Card.

name: Joe Weider
review: I’m not saying you should marry it, but the Marriott Rewards Credit Card is a pretty darn good offer, considering the fact that you get two free nights when you get approved for an account and another four when you make your first purchase.  That’s not a typo either, the Marriott Credit Card’s initial bonus can get you up to six free nights (less if you want to stay at one of Marriott’s fanciest hotels).  That means the Marriott Card isn’t only useful for brand loyal frequent travelers as is often the case with hotel or airline credit cards affiliated with specific companies.  In other words, even if you don’t stay at a Marriott Hotel on a regular basis, you could still make use of the six free nights the Marriott Credit Card gives you.  That’s not to say that loyal Marriott customers won’t benefit either because they certainly will.  The Marriott Reward Card also gives you 3 points per $1 spent at Marriott properties, 1 point per $1 spent everywhere else, and perhaps most importantly, a 10 nights credit toward Elite Status, which gets you a 20% bonus on the Marriott Rewards you earn, priority late check out, gift shop discounts, etc.  It’s therefore pretty clear that for people looking to get a lucrative hotel credit card rewards bonus or loyal Marriott customers, the Marriott Card is a good choice.But are there any better choices?  Well, Marriott also offers a Premier Credit Card, which gives you a 50,000 point initial bonus (worth about 6 free nights), one free night upon account approval, one free night each year on your account anniversary, 5 points per $1 spent at Marriott properties, 2 point per $1 on dining, airline, and rental car purchases, 1 point per $1 on everything else, and a 15 night credit toward elite status.  Therefore, the Marriott Premier Rewards Credit Card offers more lucrative rewards, but it also has an $85 annual fee beginning in the second year, whereas the plain Marriott Rewards Credit Card charges only $45.  Loyal customers should therefore decide whether the extra cost is worth the added rewards.  Initial bonus hunters should get the Premier.

name: Won Lee
review:
not only initial bonus  hunters Joe.  Everyone who can qualify for premier card (as that one requires higher credit rating) should go for premier. 

yes you pay more, but 45$ difference nets you free certificate every year you renew.  well worth $45 bux.

name: Joe Weider
review: There are a few different Chase Ink credit cards out there and the Ink Cash Business Card - $250 Bonus Cash Back should immediately appeal to small business owners who value straightforward, simple rewards.  Cash is the most straightforward rewards currency because you can immediately tell how lucrative a card will be since you don’t have to figure out what points or miles are worth and can be redeemed for.  Immediate appeal is not going to dictate the card you get though, so lets see exactly what the Ink Cash Business Credit Card has to offer.  To start the Ink Cash offers $250 cash back for spending $5,000 in the first three months. Moving forward you get 5% cash back on the first $25,000 spent on on office supplies as well as cable and phone services.  You also get 2% cash back on the first $25,000 spent on gas and dining and 1% cash back on everything else.  In terms of rates, the Ink Cash Business Card gives you 0% on both purchases and balance transfers for six months.Does it stack up?  When it comes to rewards, the Ink Cash Card is competitive but not necessarily the most lucrative.  The Ink Bold with Ultimate Rewards offers a $500 initial bonus and 5X points on the first $50,000 your company spends each year on the same types of things the Ink Cash gives you 5% cash back for, on $25,000 spent.  It doesn’t matter that it’s a charge card because when it comes to interest rates, you want to be talking about personal credit cards anyway.  They do not increase your personal liability but they do prevent issuers from changing your interest rates without cause since they are protected by the CARD Act.  There are also a couple Citicards offers 0% for 21 months, so I’d start there when looking for a card to handle funding.  Having a business credit card is still important though, and Chase’s Ink Cash Card and Ink Bold with Ultimate Rewards are both good offers, which you choose depends on how much your company spends in the first few months and throughout the year.

name: Joe Weider
review: Ink Classic kinda sounds like it could be a tattoo parlor, huh?  At any rate, Ink is the branding Chase uses for its business credit cards, and one would think that the Ink Classic would be sort of the flagship, “where it all started” type offer.  This Ink Classic Business Credit Card from Chase offers up to 25,000 bonus points – 15,000 after your first purchase and 10k after you spend $5,000 in the first three months.  It gives you five points per dollar on the first $25k you spend on office supplies, wireless services, landlines, and cable each year.  There’s also 2 points/$1 on the first 25k you spend on fuel and dining each year and 1 point/$1 spent on everything else.  The Ink Classic Business Credit Card doesn’t have an annual fee either and offers 0% on both purchases and balance transfers for 6 months.  The Ink Classic is therefore a competitive rewards business credit card that you can use for both funding and everyday expenses for the first six months.  You should not carry a balance on a Chase business credit card otherwise though because business credit cards do not have CARD Act protection, which means your issuer can change your interest rate at any time for any reason.  If you open the Ink Classic for Business Credit Card, I’d also get one of Citi’s 0% personal credit cards to use for funding purposes since Citi has three different cards offering 0% on purchases and transfers for 21 months and personal credit cards do not increase a small business owner’s personal liability, interestingly enough.  This advice would hold true with pretty much any business credit card you get for everyday spending, and I would recommend looking around a bit before ultimately deciding on the Ink Classic.  The Capital One Spark Cash for Business is a good option as well since it offers 2% cash back across all purchases.  In addition, the Chase Ink Bold has a very attractive initial bonus (twice as large as the Ink Classic’s), and even though it’s a charge card, it’s a good choice since you should be paying for in full for your everyday expenses anyway.

name: Joe Weider
review: The Ink Bold with Ultimate Rewards from Chase is the business credit card currently offering the most lucrative initial bonus.  It gives you 50,000 points when you charge $5,000 in the first three months, which is equal to $500 in cash or $625 in travel accommodations (this is the same bonus you’d get with the Chase Sapphire Preffered, by the way).  You also get 5 points per $1 on the first $50,000 in eligible business purchases you make a year, which is fantastic, and 1 point per $1 on everything else.  Chase has been recently adding companies to its lis of rewards partners, and now you can transfer Ink Bold points to the rewards programs of a number of major airlines and hotel chains at full value.  The Ink Bold’s rewards do therefore appear to be pretty ultimate, a fact which shouldn’t be all that surprising since it is a charge card.  All this means is that you won’t be given a line of credit and you will have to pay your balance in full every month, which should not actually be a deal breaker.  The reason for this is that you should ideally have one credit card for everyday expenses and another for funding.  There are a number of reasons why this is a good idea.  1) You can get both the best rewards and the longest 0% into term with two different cards 2) If you revolve a balance on a credit card, you don’t have a grace period and new purchases will incur interest immediately 3) most business credit cards do not give you debt stability because the CARD Act does not apply to small business credit cards.  In light of this info it would be a good idea to open the Ink Bold with Ultimate Rewards, use it for everyday expenses and get one of the Citicards offering 0% for 21 months (personal credit cards don’t increase your personal liability, that’s just a myth, so don’t worry).

name: Joe Weider
review: For anyone with young children its bound to be a Disney Christmas but is it going to be a Disney Christmas paid for with the Disney Credit Card?  Before you say yes or no off the cuff, it bears seeing what this card brings to the table.  With the Disney Credit Card you get 1% cash back across all purchases (standard for rewards cards), 10% off select purchases at Disney locations and DisneyStore.com (anytime words like “select” get thrown about, I get nervous) and some discounts on things like tours at Disney Parks.  It requires at least good credit for approval and the only intro rate it has is 0% on purchases for the first 12 months.Unfortunately, that’s not quite enough to warrant applying for the Disney Credit Card.  Look at it this way:  You’d have to spend over $4,000 through Disney to get the same amount of free money from the Disney Credit Card as you’d get basically from just opening the Chase Sapphire Preferred Credit Card and using for normal purchasing.  That card is therefore a much better option than the Disney Card if you want rewards and if you want 0% rates for a long time, the Citi Simplicity Card or the Citi Platinum Select Card would be the way to go since they both offer 0% on purchases and transfers for 21 months.

name: Joe Weider
review: Recently in my little credit card review series, I’ve for some reason been comparing credit cards that could be considered close family, like the various Chase Freedom credit cards and the Discover More cards.  I guess the holiday season is getting me in the family spirit, but whatever the reason let’s keep it rolling with a look at a Chase Sapphire credit card.  Like a little brother or the proverbial redheaded stepchild, the Chase Sapphire Card often lives under the shadow of the Chase Sapphire Preferred card.  You’d obviously assume that the preferred version would be preferable but we should at least see what the other guy has to offer.  The plain old Chase Sapphire Card first offers 25,000 bonus points after you charge $3,000 on it in the first three months, and these points are redeemable for $250.  Aside from that you get 2 points per dollar spent on dining and one point per dollar on everything else.  There’s no special 0% intro rate with the Chase Sapphire Card and consumers must have excellent credit for approval.  This last point is perhaps the most important because excellent credit is all you need to get the Chase Sapphire Preferred Card.For people mainly interested in getting an attractive initial bonus, the Chase Sapphire Preferred would be the way to go since it offers $50,000 bonus points, redeemable for $625 in travel or $500 in cash.  If you don’t mind switching credit cards after a year, the preferred version of the Chase Sapphire would again be preferable because it offers 2 points per dollar on travel AND dining and 1 point for everything else.  A $95 annual fee kicks in during the second year you’re an accountholder though, so you’ll want to close your account before that.  Basically 2% cash back on travel and dining and 1% on everything else isn’t really all that attractive when offset by a nearly $100 annual fee is factored in.  Ultimately then, the Chase Sapphire Card doesn’t have the word “preferred” along with it for a reason, so it should be behind it’s brother on your Christmas List.

name: Joe Weider
review: There are a few different Chase Freedom Visa offers available, so the first thing you need to do before applying for this is make sure you have the right one.  This $100 cash back + 0% Intro APR version offers a little bit of everything though so it can be kinda hard figuring out exactly what kind of consumer should get it.  This’ll become clearer as we take a look at its terms.  From the name, you obviously know that this Chase Freedom Visa credit card gives you a $100 initial bonus (after you spend $500 in the first three months) and 0% (12 months for transfers; 6 for purchases), but it also offers 5% cash back on quarterly spending categories and 1% on everything else.Let’s compare these terms to other available offers.  The $100 initial bonus the Chase Freedom Visa offers is good, but not great when you consider that cards like the Chase Sapphire Preferred offer either at least $500.  Yeah, you will probably have to spend more in the first three months to get it, but if you will spend that much anyway, that’s not a concern.  The Chase Freedom Visa’s 0% APR offers are decent as well, but you can get 0% on both transfers and purchases for 21 months with the Citi Simplicity and Platinum Select credit cards.  When it comes to rewards, you can do better than 5% on rotating categories and 1% on everything else, particularly since you have to sign up for those rotating categories and not everyone will remember to do so every quarter.  On their own, each of the Chase Freedom Visa - $100 cash back + 0% Intro APR card’s features is inferior to available options.  So what about the sum of these parts?  Getting a single card that addresses all of your needs (e.g. rewards, lowering the cost of debt, etc.) isn’t the best idea, precisely because you are unlikely to get any features that excel in their own right.  For most people, I’d recommend segmenting your needs and getting the best possible card to meet each of them.  If you want to use a 0% intro purchase APR to leave your payments in the bank longer and in doing so get interest revenue and rewards, I’d go with the Citi Dividend World MasterCard or the Discover More Card because both offer rewards at least comparable to the Chase Freedom Visa and have 0% for longer.

name: Joe Weider
review: Like with the Discover More credit cards, there are a few different Chase Freedom cards out there.  With the Chase Freedom Visa – As Low as 9.99% APR, Chase is obviously highlighting the card’s regular APR, which means that this particular offer is targeted to people who don’t want to be gouged in the months they aren’t able to pay their balance in full.  This 9.99% APR Chase Freedom Card also offers rewards though, so it might catch your eye if you don’t want to worry in months you can’t pay, but usually do so and want to full get some free money from your spending.  Whether it will meet your needs obviously depends on the particular rewards this low interest Chase Freedom Visa offers and how they stack up against other offers available to people with excellent credit history.The card’s rewards structure is pretty straightforward, you get a $50 cash bonus after your first purchase, 5% cash back on rotating spending categories that change on a quarterly basis, and 1% cash back on everything else.  This combination has become pretty standard in the current credit landscape, but it isn’t necessarily as good as it seems.  It seems that you’ll only get the 5% rate on $1,500 in charges each quarter and you have to sign up anew each quarter to even get that.  That means instead of getting convenience and more straightforward rewards (the supposed calling cards of cash back) with the Chase Freedom 9.99% APR offer, you get another quarterly obligation that comes with caveats.  If you forget to sign up for the 5% rate, you’ll just have a 1% cash back card which isn’t really competitive.  The same type of reasoning can be applied to the card’s APR.  Just because it offers a rate AS LOW AS 9.99% doesn’t mean you’ll get that rate.  In fact, only the people with the absolute best credit scores will be given it.  Your rate could end up being as high as 22.99% and you wont know what your in for at the time of application.  If it were me applying, I’d decide whether a low interest rate is really a priority (If you pay your bill in full every month, it isn’t).  If it isn’t, instead of wasting time with this Chase Freedom 9.99% APR credit card offer, I’d either get a good all-round rewards card that is inherently hassle free, like the Capital One Cash Credit Card (1.5% on all purchases) or the Venture Card (basically 2% cash back when miles redeemed for travel) or a card with the best rewards on my biggest expenses (preferably without a need to sign up for rotating categories).  If a low rate is a priority, then I’d consider my credit standing and either apply for a card like the Chase Freedom Visa with a low best case scenario APR or a card with a lower high end rate.

name: Joe Weider
review: I’ve never flown Continental Airlines, but if you have or do frequently you might be interested in the Continental Airlines OnePass Plus Credit Card.  This Continental Airlines Credit Card offers an initial rewards bonus of 30,000 miles (25,000 after you first use it and 5,000 after you add an authorized user; you have to do both within two months).  It also provides 10,000 bonus miles each year that you charge $25k.  Its regular rewards are 2 miles per $1 spent on Continental and United Airlines tickets and 1 mile per $1 spent on everything else.  The real question though is what you get with these miles.From a quick look at the Continental Airlines website, it looks like you can start getting free flights at 10,000 miles, but this lower end option is obviously a one-way economy fare for a domestic flight.  You can also redeem your Continental Airlines OnePass Plus Credit Card miles for rental cars and hotels or donate your miles to charity.  That’s pretty standard for rewards credit cards though.  The other things you get with the Continental Airlines Credit Card are one free checked bag and priority boarding on Continental and United Airlines flights and two complimentary passes to the United Club each year.  While you can redeem miles for flights on any Star Alliance airline, it really only pays to apply for the Continental Airlines OnePass Plus Credit Card if you fly at least tens of thousands of miles with Continental or United each year because such flights are the only way you’re going to get the 2 miles/ 1 dollar spent and flying frequently is the only way you’ll be able to benefit enough.
